Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on the Effectiveness of Cognitive Aids in Surgical Settings

Trial_Design.evidence: Teams were randomised to manage three simulated deteriorating patient scenarios with or without cognitive aids.

Participants.evidence: Participants were eligible if they were part of a surgical ward team.

Intervention.evidence: Teams were randomised to manage three simulated deteriorating patient scenarios with or without cognitive aids.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the effectiveness of cognitive aids in improving adherence to best practices in managing deteriorating postoperative patients.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the percentage of omitted critical management steps, measured immediately after each scenario.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not applicable due to the nature of the intervention.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Fifty surgical teams were randomised, with 25 teams in each group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Using cognitive aids reduced omitted critical management steps from 33% to 10% (70% reduction, P < .001). Multivariate analysis confirmed this effect (odds ratio, 0.63; 95% CI, −0.228 to −0.061; P = .001).
